newsitem.title: INDIA: India, China sign frontier pact to ease tensions.
newsitem.headline: India, China sign frontier pact to ease tensions.

text.p: India and China signed an agreement on Friday aimed at reducing tensions along their Himalayan frontier, over which they fought a war in 1962.
Both sides said the agreement on confidence-building measures in military areas along the line of actual control could lead to troop and weapon cutbacks.

"What has been signed is a substantive, a very useful and a forward-looking agreement, which is a major step forward," Salman Haider, the most senior civil servant in India's Foreign Ministry, told a media briefing.

Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told reporters: "The two sides today signed an agreement on confidence-building measures in the military field along the line of actual control in the border areas of India and China.
"They hope this agreement will facilitate consultative agreements between both sides," he added.
It was signed by Indian Foreign Minister Inder Kumar Gujral and Chinese counterpart Qian Qichen after talks between Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda.
Jiang is on the second day of a three-day state visit, the first to India by a Chinese president.
Indian officials said other issues raised at the Jiang-Gowda talks included Afghanistan and Chinese arms sales to Pakistan, India's traditional foe.
The issue of the 4,500-km (2,800-mile) frontier is viewed as central to problems between the two countries, home to one-third of the world's population.
The pact reaffirmed that "neither side shall use or threaten to use force against the other by any means or seek unilateral military superiority".

"The two sides shall reduce or limit the number of field army, border defence forces, para-military forces and any other mutually agreed category of armed force deployed in mutually agreed geographical zones along the line of actual control to ceilings to be mutually agreed upon," it said.

The agreement said major categories of weapons to be reduced or limited included tanks, infantry combat vehicles, guns, including howitzers, of 75 mm or more and surface-to-surface and surface-to-air missiles.
Shen, speaking through an interpreter, said: "When such an agreement is implemented, the number of the armies along this area will be reduced.
"When I refer to the reduction of military personnel, I mean the reduction will depend on the actual conditions.
"If peace and tranquillity are maintained in this area, I don't believe there is any need to maintain a large number of military personnel there," Shen added.
India and China signed an agreement in 1993 to ease tension along their frontier during a visit by former prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao to Beijing.
In August 1995, India and China agreed to pull back their troops from four border posts in India's northeastern state of Arunachal Pradesh, parts of which are claimed by China.

Haider said full implementation of the 1993 and 1996 pacts "will help in advancing the shared agenda of developing an institutionalised framework of cooperation and for moving towards troop reduction and limitation on the India-China border.
The agreement said both sides would avoid large-scale military exercises involving more than one division of approximately 15,000 troops near the line of actual control.
"However, if such exercises are to be conducted, the strategic direction of the main force involved shall not be towards the other side," it added.

The two sides also signed agreements on preventing illegal drug trafficking, direct shipping links and an Indian consular office in Hong Kong after mid-1997 when China resumes sovereignty of the territory.
Jiang goes to Agra on Saturday to visit the Taj Mahal and heads for Pakistan on Sunday.
